title: Versatile VR experience
reviews: The Quest 2 is a well designed VR headset that has the versatility to work as standalone, or connected to a PC for a wider choice of games (if the pc is up to it!). The choice of games is good and growing all the time, just search the Oculus store and you can have a look before purchasing. Don't expect cutting edge visuals in standalone mode, its essentially mobile phone hardware powering the displays. But it gives the VR experience at around half the price of some of the other VR technologies, and without having to have a high spec gaming PC. Being standalone its great to travel with, just draw out the play area and you're good to go. It works really well as a "party game", cast the display to a TV and everyone can see whats on the headset getting everyone involved in the fun. I'd recommend an alternative strap such as the elite strap or similar for a more comfortable experience.

With the ability to connect to a PC/Laptop either through a link cable (£20 ish) or using air link via the Wifi you can play a multitude of games using for example steamVR, But there is plenty of content without the need to even own a PC/Laptop. If you wear glasses, not an issue the Quest 2 comes with a spacer to help but, I have found I don't need this and my glasses don't touch the lenses in the headset (which could scratch the lenses in the headset). The headset is fairly comfortable to wear however you do need to fiddle to get the lenses in the "sweet spot" otherwise you get a blurry view, however once you figure it out it is easy to get the correct position within a few seconds of putting it on. There are apps for experiencining 3D movies, full 360 degree events like a music concerts, educational films, museums, historic sites, an ISS tour or even a space walk and genuinely tons more. Google Earth VR is fantastic. All in all I love the quest 2 and have no hesitation in recommending it to others looking to get into VR, at this price point it truly is great value for money, And at no point have I been dissapointed.

title: Great VR experience
reviews: Have waited a long time for this and I'm glad I finally got it. There's a great, but small, range of games, fitness, and lots of free entertainment (and paid for - eg films or concerts). Beat Saber, for example, is even better without having to worry about pulling out or stepping on the cable (I have a PSVR). Check out some of the FB groups and get a referral code for store credit - enough for Beat Saber to be free right now. It's also great to be able to play in different places (I've read about people using it while travelling or in their hotel) - I've also watched some YouTube VR and tried the Space Station experience while lying in bed. I recommend trying Bigscreen - you can watch things in your own virtual cinema (you can choose different types of location and your spot in front of the screen) by yourself, or with friends. You can also attend shows and concerts if you pay extra. Fitness is one of the main reasons I got this - boxing games, sport and gym games, music games .. and the distraction of the game really helps keep you going. However, there are some negatives - the headset isn't comfortable straight out of the box. You really need to get a different strap or attachment- check out reviews on YouTube to help you decide. There are better foam attachments for the part that touches your face, and grips for the controllers because the surface is too smooth. It's annoying that you can need so many extras, but you should get them, it's worth the extra money. Also, you can easily use it without a PC, but this also means you're missing out on a much bigger range of games and better graphics - eg the latest Half Life game. Overall, it's a great introduction to VR, in many ways it's much better than the PSVR and there are some amazing experiences waiting for you. But make sure you check out some of the YT reviews to help you get the most out of it.

title: Oculus Quest 2
reviews: Design: The headset looks sleek and well designed. I would recommend fitting the provided glasses spacer and silicone cover before even using the headset, which improves comfort considerably. If you are not used to wearing a headset, the weight on your head can feel uncomfortable initially, but it is not a deal-breaker as this is something that you get used to over time. One thing to note, there are only 3 lens settings for IPD (distance between eyes). However, these 3 options should accommodate most people. Battery life: Roughly 2.5 hours from a full charge, which, if you think about it, is pretty good considering it is a standalone product and is not wired to anything. However, it does charge quickly with the provided charger, which is good. If you want to use it for extended periods, make sure you have a long USB-C cable and plug it into the mains as the one provided is very short (keep in mind, the headset may get warm during extended use.) Connectivity: Simple as can be, turn the headset on and away you go. I recommend Oculus Link (or Air Link, which is even better if you have the internet speed for it!) if you have a gaming PC alongside the headset. Oculus/Air Link will enable you to play SteamVR titles such as Half-Life: Alyx etc., which wouldn't be otherwise available on the Quest 2. Ease of use: Impossibly easy setup and general use, but you require a FaceBook account, which isn't ideal. Also, you will need money aside to buy games/applications, so keep that in mind - there are some free applications, but for fully-fledged experiences, you'll most likely need some extra money. In conclusion, I would recommend the Quest 2 to people looking for an introduction to VR and people who have experienced VR in the past. For the price, nothing in the market can currently beat it.

title: Comfortable, convenient and safe
reviews: I was wary at first because tech reviews on YouTube said the basic strap is uncomfortable but honestly I find it absolutely fine. If you're someone who isn't always home and has children then it's well worth it as it's easy to carry around, though I do recommend getting silicone covers for the controllers and especially protection for the lenses, as the cost of fixing the lenses is so high you may as well buy a whole new headset. The best thing about the Oculus is the safety features, you create the boundaries around your living room and it will warn you if you're stepping outside of them. Once you step outside them you can see everything around you. It can break immersion in games at times but it's a still a feature best to have. It does have 2 hour battery life which can be extended by getting an external battery, but especially for children I think 2 hours is enough. I have been told its best not to plug it into the mains to play it as it can potentially damage it.

title: Great headset, shame about the strap
reviews: I've had this headset for a few weeks now, it was easy to set up - brand new condition - and much more lightweight in comparison to the Quest 1. (If using a Link cable) it also holds charge for a good few hours. Getting set up to play via the PC was a bit of a hasstle but once it has been it's now a very straightforward process. When in-game, the Oculus app is okay to use, not the best but it's easy to figure out. Sometimes the loading screens between games/steam/virtual desktop can lag/jitter, this is something to get use to. The main downside to this product is the strap quality. It's awful and very uncomfortable. I had to buy an alternative strap to make this wearable. For the price, I would have expected a much better quality strap to come with the product. The face visors are also not the best. The sponge one causes skin burn and soaks up sweat making it very unhygienic. The silicon one although easier to clean is very hard and does cause some strain. Again, I would reccomend buying a soft padded face visor for this item. I've done this and it makes wearing time much more pleasent! If purchasing for a young person/child, due to weight and comfort I highly recommend buying a better (weighted) head strap and face visor. Overall, it's a very good product, much better than the Quest 1, great charging hold, and lost of great games to enjoy!

title: It's mediocre
reviews: First things first, you are forced to have a Facebook account and this is a major negative right from the start. The headset strap is very uncomfortable and the battery is shocking, it takes hours to charge and you only get a 2 or so hours play time. Now I know you can buy a elite strap and battery but this should be standard for the price, not an additional sell. The elite strap and battery do work and makes it comfortable and gives you approx 4 to 5 hours. The other negative is the headset gets hot, sometimes it's so hot I can feel the heat on my eye balls drying them out. Personally for me the resolution is no great and although there is no screen door effect, instead that's replaced with just as annoying ring door effect where you can see rings that make it unclear and crisp to the eye. The good thing is that it is enjoyable to use once you use sidequest to increase resolution and performance, you can even install retro games like Half Life and Doom 3 in VR using side quest. I really like Resident evil 4 VR and some other games from Oculus. Oculus TV is rubbish the quality is like 420P on 360 videos, the best result is YouTube VR and Big screen for clarity. Overall, although fun to use, I still think VR is a long way off in terms of a good enjoyable experience that you can keep going back too. If I was to improve this it would be a better way to disperse heat, improve graphics massively and get rid of the rings that cause blurry vision as I have to constantly adjust the headset

title: Almost there..
reviews: I bought this for my husband as a Christmas present. He had an Oculus Rift before this. This is definitely an upgrade on the rift, with smooth, crisp graphics and of course the ability to use the headset as a wire free standalone device you can just take with you anywhere. However, there's a few negatives to mention. First off, you will need to get a better strap straight away. The strap supplied does not have enough support for the front- heavy headset and it is extremely uncomfortable to wear, as it drags down at the front of your face. The elite strap is very good (adjustable at the back with a dial). However, it's very expensive, especially the one with an extra battery pack at the back. The elite strap does secure the quest 2 nicely on the head though, and the battery pack at the back balances out the weight distribution a bit. I would also recommend getting a USB A to USB C (3.0) cable as you will probably want to play it wired at home and it doesn't come with any wired connections. Overall, this is a step in the right direction with VR. Not ground breaking if you already have a decent VR set. And unless you have all your games on the Oculus store, you may find you want to use the vr set wired.

title: You'll go "wow" at least once
reviews: Pros: It's pretty easy to set up (there are useful 'how to get started' videos on YouTube) and to use. Once you've got it set up, you'll find some intros that take you through what it can do and how to use it. It comes with preloaded experiences and demo versions of games so you'll have stuff to keep you busy for a while (I've had mine three weeks and still haven't seen and done everything on it). There's a variety of things to do. Apart from games and fitness classes, I've been snowboarding, experienced a parachute jump, raced a motorbike and visited places I've never been before (plus a few I have). You'll go "Wow" at least once. Cons: Oculus is owned by Facebook and you need a facebook account to use it. You'll want to buy full versions of some of the games, as well as new stuff, and these are not cheap. It's a bit glitchy - it can freeze, for example - but most problems are resolved by restarting it (the Oculus website is quite useful, you can even chat to a real person). Spending hours in virtual reality might be a bit antisocial to people around you. Overall, I'm pleased with it and have used it nearly every day. If you've never experienced immersive VR before, you'll find it very different from anything else - including 3D. But that's what makes you go "wow".

title: Must have, for a beginner to veteran gamer.
reviews: This is an awesome VR headset. Facebook/Meta have packed so much tech into this fully wireless device. If you're interest in VR, whether it's simply just to explore what it has to offer or if you want to start with PCVR gaming this device can do it. The tiny android mobile chip in this thing is truly impressive and can perform really well on its own, but if you need more power and better graphics, you can wire up via USB-C or connect wirelessly (5ghz ONLY) to your PC to really experience VR. Tracking is fantastic and you don't need any additional equipment like most VR devices (such as trackers etc) Battery will last approx 2-3 hours but you can charge whilst you play, if you have a long enough USB-C Cable (cheap one from Amazon will suffice) Do yourself a favour and visit VR, you won't be disappointed, especially to impress family & friends.

If you are the techy type, there are ways to connect your Oculus to your PC and Steam, so that will increase your options in terms of games to play. I would recommend also going for the accessories if you plan to spend longer hours on the Quest 2.

title: Lovely device for gamers or those wanting to relax
reviews: I bought this as a replacement for the Quest 1 which recently broke. Compared to the Quest 1, the build quality is inferior but this is balanced by the display quality which is noticeably better. If you have never used a VR headset before, don't expect immersion like you've seen in films as we are a few years away from spending your life in a new, exciting fun filled world. What you do get is an introduction into what will come. Many people complain that any VR headset makes their neck or head ache. This is usually down you not adjusting it correctly and there are tones of YouTube clips on how to do this right. Many people sweat where the visor meets the face but i just wipe my visor with moist wipes to keep it clean. Motion sickness effects lots of new owners and has forced many to get rid of their headset, but you can train your sensors to ignore the discrepancy between your balance and eyes. If you run 'calm' apps until you have adjusted then most people can overcome the motion sickness in a couple of weeks. Jump straight into the roller-coaster and you'll struggle. when you start to feel ill, you need to stop straight away as you will not be able to push through it. It will win every time. There are accessories you can buy for this VR headset but the only one i have is an external battery holder which i 3D printed myself. This gives added play time and, as its attached to the back strap, it's a counterweight for the headset which helps with neck pain. I have been a video games since space invaders and Atari but i was blown away when i tried my first VR headset and would encourage anyone to try it. There are relaxation apps which have been a godsend during isolation and exercise apps which will put you through your paces. For the price, £100 cheaper than the Quest 1 was, this is such a useful device.
